items.title: Bezos-backed EV startup Slate Auto’s pickup truck spotted in the wild
The US Secretary of Education referred to AI as ‘A1,’ like the steak sauce
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- U.S. Secretary of Education Linda McMahon referred to AI as 'A1' during the ASU+GSV Summit.
- She discussed the importance of technology in education, aiming for comprehensive AI integration in early grades.
- McMahon's inconsistent use of 'A1' and 'AI' raised eyebrows, highlighting a potential oversight from an education leader.

items.title: Netflix’s latest season of ‘Black Mirror’ comes with a mobile game
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Season 7 of “Black Mirror” premiered on April 10, 2025, introducing the mobile game “Thronglets.”
- The game, developed by Night School Studio, is a companion to the episode titled “Plaything.”
- Players interact with virtual yellow pets that can replicate and evolve, requiring careful management to keep them alive.
- Unlike simple games like Tamagotchi, the creatures are sentient and provide feedback to players on their actions.
- Available for Netflix subscribers on iOS and Android, Thronglets represents a strategic focus on narrative games linked to shows.
- The launch is part of Netflix’s revised gaming strategy, which includes main categories of narrative, multiplayer, kids, and mainstream games.

items.title: Jobandtalent raises $103M on a down-round $1.5B valuation as it looks to AI to recruit temps
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Jobandtalent raised €92 million ($103 million) in a Series F funding round, valuing the company at €1.3 billion ($1.5 billion) post-money.
- This funding round is a down round, contrasting with their previous Series E at $2.35 billion in December 2021.
- The company operates in 10 countries and has placed over 300,000 workers in roles at 3,250 companies, focusing on logistics and retail.
- The new capital will be used to scale internationally and integrate AI agents into their platform, including a recruitment agent named Clara, which has conducted 180,000 interviews and facilitated 7,000 hires.
- Jobandtalent aims to evolve into a fully integrated employment platform, addressing challenges in the post-COVID European labor market influenced by economic changes and AI technology.

items.title: LiveKit’s tools power real-time communications, including OpenAI’s Voice Mode
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- LiveKit is an open-source software for real-time audio and video communication, launched in 2021.
- It has over 500 paying customers and is the backbone for roughly 25% of 911 emergency calls in the U.S.
- Major companies using LiveKit include Spotify, Meta, and Microsoft.
- LiveKit recently raised $45 million in a Series B funding round, with a run rate over $10 million.
- The company is developing an AI-native cloud provider focused on communications.

items.title: Canva is getting AI image generation, interactive coding, spreadsheets and more
OpenAI updates ChatGPT to reference your past chats
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced a new memory feature in ChatGPT to tailor responses based on previous conversations.
- Feature titled 'reference saved memories' will initially roll out to ChatGPT Pro and Plus subscribers, excluding certain regions due to regulatory reviews.
- Users can opt-out of the memory feature, manage saved memories, and ask ChatGPT what it remembers.

items.title: Meghan Markle has made another angel investment
items.summary:
- Meghan Markle is expanding her angel investing portfolio, focusing on companies with female founders.
- She has invested in the healthcare company Midi, which helps women with menopause and related health issues.
- Markle participated in Midi's $63 million Series B funding round, which included notable investors like Laurene Powell Jobs and Tory Burch.
- She has been actively investing in diverse sectors since moving to the U.S. five years ago, building a portfolio of over 10 companies including consumer and wellness brands.

items.title: Glossier might lose its unicorn status, report says
items.summary:
- Glossier is reportedly seeking to raise $100 million at a valuation below $1 billion.
- The last valuation was $1.8 billion nearly four years ago, but the company has faced challenges with profitability and growth.
- The brand seeks new consumer-oriented investors and a refreshed board amid a changing direct-to-consumer market.

items.title: Sydney Thomas’s Symphonic Capital raises $13.5M for inaugural fund
YouTube rolls out a free AI music-making tool for creators
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- YouTube is launching an AI music-making tool allowing creators to generate custom instrumental music for their videos.
- The feature is being rolled out gradually to creators using the Creator Music marketplace.
- Creators can specify details like instruments and mood to create their tracks via a 'Music Assistant' tab in Creator Music.
- Generated music can be downloaded and used freely without copyright concerns.
- This new feature follows a previous tool called 'Dream Track', focusing solely on instrumental music.

items.title: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy urges companies to invest heavily in AI
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Amazon CEO Andy Jassy advocates for aggressive AI investment to secure future financial rewards.
- Jassy's annual letter emphasized the need for substantial capital to keep pace with AI innovation and consumer demand.
- Amazon plans to spend over $100 billion on capital expenditures in 2025, primarily on AWS AI capabilities.
- Current major expenses include data centers and chips, but costs are expected to reduce over time.
- Amazon's Trainium2 chips, released in late 2024, offer 30%-40% better price-performance compared to GPU-powered instances.
- AI revenue at Amazon is growing at triple-digit percentages and represents a multi-billion-dollar annual run rate.

items.title: Rebooted Digg launches early-access community with $5 fee
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- The reboot of Digg, led by original founder Kevin Rose and Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian, launches an early-access community called "Groundbreakers".
- Joining costs $5, which will support a nonprofit selected by the community, rather than generate profit.
- Members gain access to updates, mockups, and experiments, as well as the chance to secure usernames and display a "Groundbreakers badge".
- The community operates on the Circle platform, initially facing some signup issues, but nearly 3,000 members had joined by publication time.

items.title: Google thinks AI can untangle the electrical grid’s bureaucracy
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Google and PJM are partnering to develop AI models to streamline the electrical grid’s application process.
- There are 2.6 terawatts of generating capacity waiting for approval nationally, with PJM managing the largest backlog of over 3,000 requests for 286.7 gigawatts.
- The new approval process for PJM may prioritize fossil fuel projects over renewable energy initiatives.

items.title: NHTSA’s self-driving safety staff reportedly ‘disproportionally affected’ by DOGE cuts
items.summary:
- Cuts at NHTSA's vehicle automation safety division disproportionately affected employees involved in this area.
- Approximately 30 employees were let go; many were still in their initial probationary hiring period.
- Affected workers fear these cuts will weaken NHTSA’s understanding of self-driving technologies.
- The layoffs occurred shortly before Tesla’s first robotaxi service launch in Austin, with plans for expansion to California and beyond later this year.

items.title: WhatsApp introduces new features across chats, calls, and channels
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- WhatsApp announced new updates to enhance chats, calls, and channels competition with Telegram and Discord.
- Notable features include an “Online” indicator in group chats and a “Notify for” setting to manage notifications.
- iPhone users can now scan and send documents, set WhatsApp as the default app, and pinch to zoom during video calls.
- The app's technology improvements aim to enhance video call quality and reliability.
- Users can create events in 1:1 conversations with new RSVP options and add participants to ongoing calls.
- Channels receive updates allowing admins to share videos, QR codes, and summaries of voice messages.

items.title: Inventex founder, an engineer for Coinbase at 14, wants to revolutionize patent applications
items.summary:
- Daniel Ruskin started working as an engineer for Coinbase at 14, developing key software for the platform.
- Frustrated by the patent process, he founded Inventex in December 2024 to streamline patent applications using AI agents and licensed attorneys.
- Inventex raised $2.4 million in a pre-seed funding round to expedite patent-pending applications and improve quality.
- The company plans to automate patent filings, aiming for a tenfold increase in efficiency compared to traditional methods.
- Ruskin's experience includes building a neobank at Checkr and graduating from law school in 2024.

items.title: Polestar EV sales jump in Q1 on discounts like its ‘Tesla conquest’ bonus
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Polestar's Q1 sales increased by 76% compared to Q1 2024, selling 12,304 cars.
- The growth was fueled by discounts, including a $5,000 incentive for Tesla owners.
- CEO Michael Lohscheller expressed positivity about the company's direction and sales strategies.
- Polestar competes amidst a challenging economic environment and other automakers.
- The company is preparing to launch the Polestar 4 SUV coupe later in 2025, while monitoring market conditions in China.
- An end to a joint venture in China was announced to refocus on the Chinese market, despite challenges from geopolitical factors and market strategy changes.

items.title: Canoo CEO can buy bankrupt EV startup’s assets, judge rules
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- A judge approved the sale of Canoo’s assets to CEO Anthony Aquila for approximately $4 million in cash.
- The judge stated that the sale process was fair and that no other bids were made.
- The assets will support services for customers like NASA and the Department of Defense.
- Several parties, including Harbinger, evaluated the assets but did not bid due to concerns around foreign ownership and legal disputes.
- The sale's finalization was contested due to ongoing litigation regarding trade secrets between Canoo and Harbinger, but the judge ruled the process legitimate.

items.title: Incident.io raises $62M at a $400M valuation to help IT teams move fast when things break
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Incident.io raised $62 million in financing, led by Insight Partners, with participation from Index and Point Nine.
- The London-based startup aims to enhance incident management and response for IT teams.
- Incident.io has now raised over $96 million and is valued at around $400 million.
- The company targets organizations with over 200 users and has tripled its customer base in the past year, including clients like Netflix and Etsy.
- New product features include integration with Microsoft Teams, an on-call management product, and AI capabilities to streamline incident handling.

items.title: Trump orders federal investigation into former CISA director Chris Krebs
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- President Trump ordered a federal investigation into Chris Krebs, the former director of CISA.
- The executive order revokes Krebs’ security clearance and claims he denied that the 2020 election was rigged.
- Trump’s accusations against Krebs align with his ongoing claims of voting irregularities without substantiating evidence.
- Krebs previously oversaw efforts to combat misinformation about election integrity during his tenure at CISA.
- The order also affects security clearances of employees at SentinelOne, Krebs' current employer.
- Trump signed another executive order revoking the clearance of a former Homeland Security official who criticized his policies.

items.title: The rise of AI ‘reasoning’ models is making benchmarking more expensive
items.summary:
- AI labs like OpenAI claim reasoning AI models are more capable than non-reasoning counterparts but are costly to benchmark.
- Evaluating OpenAI’s o1 model costs $2,767.05 across seven benchmarks; Anthropic's Claude 3.7 costs $1,485.35.
- Artificial Analysis has spent approximately $5,200 on reasoning model evaluations, nearly double what they spent on non-reasoning models.

items.title: Drafted uses AI and video resumes to help early-career professionals land jobs
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Drafted is a new jobs platform targeting students and early-career professionals.
- It uses AI and video resumes to match candidates with jobs, moving beyond traditional keyword matching.
- The platform partners with over 3,500 companies, including major firms like Google, Amazon, and DoorDash.
- Founders Andrew Kozlovski and Rodrigo Pecchio created the platform to address the struggles faced by startups and entry-level job seekers.
- Job seekers create video resumes answering typical recruiter questions, which employers can filter and review.
- Drafted plans to keep the platform free for job seekers and will implement a subscription model for employers in the future.

items.title: AI insurtech Ominimo bags its first investment at a $220M valuation
items.summary:
- Ominimo, an insurance startup from Poland, raises €10 million from Zurich Insurance Group for 5% equity, valuing the company at $220 million.
- The startup has signed up 300,000 policies in Hungary and aims to expand into more than 10 new markets.
- Ominimo uses AI-based analytics to price insurance, applying more parameters than traditional insurers, and is already profitable with a 7% market share in Hungary.

items.title: Revent rocks the boat with a fresh $100M to invest in people and the planet
A fresh $100M rolls into DIG Ventures as it bids to woo early-stage European startups
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- DIG Ventures launched its second fund, raising $100 million for investments in B2B SaaS, AI, and cloud infrastructure startups.
- The fund targets pre-seed and seed stages, primarily in Europe, Israel, and the U.S.
- Notable LPs include The Hillman Company, Granite Capital, Sofina, and Grove Street, along with investments from prominent figures like Datadog founder Olivier Pomel.
- The fund aims to support companies with technical products, enhancing their go-to-market strategies.
- Founders Mason and Klinger emphasize the unique capabilities of operator VCs in navigating technical products and fundraising in Europe.

items.title: Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, launches an API for Grok 3
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's company xAI launches an API for its AI model, Grok 3.
- Grok 3 can analyze images and respond to questions, potentially competing with models like OpenAI's GPT-4o and Google's Gemini.
- The article details pricing for Grok 3 at $3 per million tokens input and $15 for output, with a cheaper Grok 3 Mini option.
- There are concerns regarding Grok 3's smaller context window, maxing out at 131,072 tokens vs. the claimed 1 million.
- Musk aims to make Grok politically neutral, although past versions have displayed a leftist bias on certain topics.

items.title: Wayve’s self-driving tech is headed to Nissan vehicles
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Nissan will integrate Wayve’s self-driving software into its advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) starting in 2027.
- This partnership marks a significant deal for Wayve, which has raised over $1.3 billion from major investors like Nvidia and Microsoft.
- The system will operate at Level 2 automation, requiring driver supervision but automating multiple driving tasks.
- Wayve’s technology is self-learning, designed to work with existing sensors, making it adaptable across various environments and vehicles.
- Future Nissan vehicles are expected to replicate human driver behavior in complex scenarios through this collaboration.

items.title: How a hydrogen explosion led a teenage founder to become Sequoia’s first defense tech investment
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Mach Industries, founded by Ethan Thornton, raised over $80 million since its launch in 2023.
- The company experienced a setback when a hydrogen gun prototype exploded, injuring a team member.
- Following the explosion, Mach secured funding from Sequoia Capital and is now collaborating with the U.S. military on new weapons, including a cruise missile and a bomb called "Glide."

items.title: Google embraces Anthropic’s standard for connecting AI models to data
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google will support Anthropic’s Model Context Protocol (MCP) for its Gemini models and SDK.
- This decision follows OpenAI's announcement to adopt the same protocol.
- MCP enables AI to draw data from various sources, facilitating two-way connections between data and applications.
- Companies like Block, Apollo, Replit, Codeium, and Sourcegraph have already integrated MCP support.

items.title: Solid, which claimed to be the ‘AWS of fintech,’ files for bankruptcy after raising nearly $81M in funding
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Solid, a banking-as-a-service startup, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on April 7, 2025.
- The company raised nearly $81 million from investors like FTV Capital and Headline since its founding in 2018.
- Solid was valued at $330 million as of August 2022 and claimed to have grown significantly in revenue and customers.
- The startup faced significant litigation, including a lawsuit from FTV Capital regarding its financial disclosures.
- Solid’s bankruptcy filing noted unsecured trade debt of about $760,000 and $7 million in cash, with only three employees remaining.
- The company is restructuring under subchapter V, allowing for expedited reorganization.
- Previous fintech bankruptcy cases have seen similar challenges, with partners like Evolve Bank & Trust involved.

items.title: OpenAI counter-sues, calls for Musk to be enjoined from ‘further unlawful and unfair action’
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI has filed a counter-suit against Elon Musk, calling for him to be stopped from further actions deemed unlawful and unfair.
- The filing suggests Musk's actions have harmed OpenAI's operations and risks to public interest, especially after a fake takeover bid.
- Musk's lawsuit claims OpenAI has diverted from its original nonprofit mission, having transitioned to a capped-profit structure.
- The case is set for jury trial in spring 2026, following Musk's failed preliminary injunction against OpenAI's for-profit transition.
- OpenAI defends its for-profit conversion as a means to support its nonprofit initiatives and has faced concerns from various organizations about its mission and charitable assets.

items.title: a16z backs Base Power in $200M round for home backup batteries
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Base Power raised $200 million for expansion and to build a domestic battery factory.
- The startup has grown rapidly, becoming one of the largest battery fleets in Texas within less than a year.
- Base Power's batteries offer a capacity of 25 or 50 kilowatt-hours for $595 or $995, significantly cheaper than Tesla’s Powerwall.
- Customers must commit to purchasing electricity for three years at 9 cents per kWh plus delivery fees and pay an annual fee of $225 to $345.
- The funding will expedite installations and expansion into new states, aiming for 100 megawatt-hours this summer.

items.title: Meta whistleblower Sarah Wynn-Williams says company targeted ads at teens based on their ’emotional state’
items.author: Sarah Wynn-Williams
items.summary:
- Meta whistleblower Sarah Wynn-Williams testified that the company targeted ads at teenagers based on their emotional states.
- During her testimony, she revealed that Meta would use data about when teens felt down to inform advertisers.
- Wynn-Williams highlighted specific practices, like targeting ads for beauty products or weight loss to teens feeling insecure about their appearance.
- The hearing also focused on Meta's dealings with China amid concerns about its impact on youth mental health.

items.title: A Waymo robotaxi got trapped in Chick-fil-A drive-through
items.summary:
- A Waymo robotaxi got stuck in a Chick-fil-A drive-thru, causing a traffic jam.
- The incident occurred after the robotaxi dropped off a passenger and failed to complete a turn due to space constraints.
- No injuries reported, just delays for patrons waiting for food.
- Waymo acknowledged previous issues with its robotaxis causing traffic disturbances, including getting stuck in a roundabout and other incidents.
- Waymo operates in San Francisco, Phoenix, Los Angeles, and has a partnership with Uber in Austin.

items.title: Whistleblower Sarah Wynn-Williams accuses Meta of colluding with China
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Sarah Wynn-Williams, former Head of Global Public Policy at Facebook, testified about Meta's alleged collaboration with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).
- She claims Meta developed censorship tools that allowed the CCP significant control over content moderation, including potential service shutdowns.
- In response, Meta denied the allegations, calling her testimony unfounded and reaffirming that it doesn't operate services in China today.
- Wynn-Williams' testimony is connected to her book, "Careless People: A Cautionary Tale of Power, Greed, and Lost Idealism," which has gained popularity despite an arbitration ruling against her.
- During her testimony, she revealed internal discussions suggesting Meta considered sharing user data with the Chinese government, especially amidst pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.
- She highlighted the existence of virality counters linked to censorship functions, including in Hong Kong and Taiwan, contradicting Zuckerberg's previous statements.
- Wynn-Williams criticized Zuckerberg's public persona, accusing him of masking business operations in China while promoting American values.

items.title: Nvidia’s H20 AI chips may be spared from export controls — for now
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang reportedly struck a deal with the Trump administration to avoid export restrictions on H20 AI chips.
- The H20 AI chips were spared from restrictions due to Huang's promise to invest in U.S. AI data centers.
- Trump’s administration had been preparing to implement export controls on these chips prior to the reversal.
- The decision appears contradictory to the U.S. goal of keeping AI dominance, as export rules remain in place for most countries, particularly China.
- Nvidia criticized the existing export guidelines as likely to stifle global innovation.

items.title: Threads is testing a feature that lets you follow the same creators you follow on X
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Meta is testing a new feature in Threads that allows users to follow creators they already follow on X.
- The feature aims to help creators and users transition from X to Threads, where they may have lost their followings.
- Users of the Threads app are being shown a pop-up to find popular creators from X and import their following list.
- The feature is currently in beta testing; it is unclear how Meta will match creators across platforms.
- Threads has grown its user base to over 320 million monthly active users as of January 2025, indicating its competitiveness against X.

items.title: Ilya Sutskever taps Google Cloud to power his AI startup’s research
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Ilya Sutskever's startup Safe Superintelligence (SSI) partners with Google Cloud to utilize TPU chips for AI research.
- SSI aims to develop safe, superintelligent AI, accelerating research and development efforts.
- The company has backing of $1 billion from Andreessen Horowitz and others, having emerged from stealth in June 2024.

items.title: Canoo CEO can buy bankrupt EV startup’s assets, judge rules
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
• Judge Brendan Shannon approves sale of Canoo’s assets to CEO Anthony Aquila for $4 million.
• Aquila plans to service customers like NASA and the Department of Defense.
• Canoo is part of a trend of bankrupt EV startups, including Fisker and Nikola.
• Harbinger, an electric truck startup, claimed Canoo hid assets, raising concerns.
• Shannon deemed the sale process fair and claims of misappropriated trade secrets unsubstantiated.

items.title: Court document reveals locations of WhatsApp victims targeted by NSO spyware
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- NSO Group’s Pegusus spyware targeted 1,223 WhatsApp users in 51 countries during a 2019 campaign.
- The most affected countries included Mexico (456 victims), India (100), and Bahrain (82).
- The hacking occurred over two months, leading to WhatsApp's lawsuit against NSO Group for exploiting the app's vulnerabilities.

items.title: More good news for New York startups: Lerer Hippeau raised another $200M
items.summary:
- Lerer Hippeau closed its ninth fund with $200 million, up from the previous fund of $140 million.
- The firm, founded in 2010, now has $1.4 billion in assets under management.
- Lerer Hippeau has invested in several notable startups including Allbirds and Warby Parker, contributing to the New York startup ecosystem.

items.title: OpenAI launches program to design new ‘domain-specific’ AI benchmarks
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI launches the Pioneers Program to create better AI model evaluations.
- The program aims to develop domain-specific benchmarks for industries like legal, finance, and healthcare.
- OpenAI intends to work with multiple companies and startups to establish these benchmarks and improve AI performance in practical applications.

items.title: Anthropic rolls out a $200-per-month Claude subscription
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Anthropic launches a new subscription plan for its AI chatbot Claude called Max, available for $100 and $200 per month.
- The higher tiers offer significantly increased usage limits compared to the existing $20-per-month Claude Pro subscription.
- The launch is seen as a strategy to increase revenue amid growing competition with OpenAI's $200-a-month ChatGPT Pro.
- The $200 Max option provides 20x higher rate limits than Claude Pro.
- Anthropic is exploring additional revenue channels, including a subscription targeting educational institutions.
- The demand for Claude subscriptions coincides with the success of their new Claude 3.7 Sonnet AI model.

items.title: Kalshi CEO: ‘State law doesn’t really apply’ to us
items.author: Tarek Mansour
items.summary:
- Kalshi, a prediction market startup, sued New Jersey and Nevada after those states attempted to shut down its sports trading operation.
- CEO Tarek Mansour argues that state gaming commissions have no authority over federally regulated platforms like Kalshi.
- A recent federal ruling allows Kalshi to continue operating in Nevada while the lawsuit is ongoing.
- Six states, including New Jersey and Nevada, sent cease-and-desist letters to Kalshi, claiming its operations are illegal sports betting.
- Mansour claims the cease-and-desist orders are motivated by a 'massive casino lobby' unhappy with Kalshi's business model.
- Kalshi recently transitioned from political betting markets to sports predictions, covering events such as March Madness and the Super Bowl.
- The outcome of this legal battle could clarify the regulatory landscape for prediction markets, which exist in a gray area of the law.

items.title: MIT study finds that AI doesn’t, in fact, have values
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A recent MIT study challenges the notion that AI systems develop coherent value systems.
- Co-authors emphasize that aligning AI could be more complex than previously thought.
- Models evaluated display inconsistent preferences, influenced by prompt wording and context.
- Models seen as imitators rather than having stable beliefs, according to co-author Stephen Casper.
- Other experts caution against anthropomorphizing AI capabilities and understanding its limitations.

items.title: YouTube expands its ‘likeness’ detection technology, which detects AI fakes, to a handful of top creators
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- YouTube announced an expansion of its pilot program to identify AI-generated content featuring creators' likenesses.
- The initiative supports the NO FAKES ACT, aimed at combating misleading AI-generated replicas.
- Initial pilot testers include prominent creators like MrBeast, Mark Rober, and Marques Brownlee.
- The program seeks to balance protection with innovation by enabling individuals to report harmful AI likenesses.
- YouTube previously collaborated with the Creative Artists Agency to develop the likeness detection system, introducing it in December 2024.

items.title: Senator puts hold on Trump’s nominee for CISA director, citing telco security ‘cover up’
US may fine TSMC $1B over chip allegedly used in Huawei AI processor
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- TSMC may face a $1 billion fine over a U.S. export control investigation involving a chip for Huawei's AI processor.
- The investigation relates to TSMC's chips used in Huawei's Ascend 910B AI processor.
- TSMC has not supplied to Huawei since mid-September 2020 and emphasizes compliance with export regulations.

items.title: Tired of doing laundry? These startups want to help.
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Startups are emerging to streamline laundry services, attracting venture capital.
- NoScrubs raised $2 million for its on-demand laundry delivery service, aiming for rapid turnaround in Austin.
- Rinse, operational since 2013, raised $23 million and serves multiple U.S. cities, emphasizing employee labor over contractors.
